name: 2.Dataset Description and Preparation
content:
Data Overview

The dataset provides patient demographics, admission details, and hospital resource information that can be used to predict hospital stay duration. Each feature contributes valuable insights into patient conditions and hospital capacity, directly influencing length of stay.


Data Description

VisitorswithPatient

  • Description: Number of visitors accompanying the patient, indicating social/family support that may influence recovery.
  • Type: Numerical.

Ward_Type

  • Description: Type of ward (General, Semi-private, Private, ICU), each offering different levels of care and recovery environments.
  • Type: Categorical.

BedGrade

  • Description: Grade of the bed (e.g., Standard, Deluxe), reflecting comfort and facilities. Higher grades may correlate with faster recovery.
  • Type: Categorical/Numerical.

TypeofAdmission

  • Description: Admission type (Emergency, Urgent, Elective), closely tied to condition severity and expected length of stay.
  • Type: Categorical.

AvailableExtraRoomsinHospital

  • Description: Number of additional rooms available in the hospital, representing hospital capacity and patient flow.
  • Type: Numerical.

Admission_Deposit

  • Description: Initial deposit amount paid upon admission, indicating the level of care the patient might access.
  • Type: Numerical.

SeverityofIllness

  • Description: Severity level of illness (Minor, Moderate, Severe), directly impacting hospital stay duration.
  • Type: Categorical.

Ward_Facility_Code

  • Description: Code representing facilities available in the ward, associated with care quality and recovery time.
  • Type: Categorical.


Data Preparation

1. Handling Missing Values

  • Step: Detect and address missing entries.
  • Approach:
  • Impute missing numerical values (e.g., Admission_Deposit, VisitorswithPatient) using mean/median.
  • Fill missing categorical values (e.g., Ward_Type, SeverityofIllness) with mode or assign an “Unknown” category.

2. Feature Encoding

  • Step: Convert categorical features into ML-friendly format.
  • Approach:
  • For H2O XGBoost, apply one-hot encoding on categorical features like Ward_Type, TypeofAdmission, SeverityofIllness.
  • For H2O Distributed Random Forest, retain categorical encoding (H2O handles categorical splits natively).

3. Scaling & Normalization

  • Step: Standardize numerical features to avoid bias from scale differences.
  • Approach:
  • Apply z-score standardization to features such as VisitorswithPatient, Admission_Deposit, and AvailableExtraRoomsinHospital.
  • Ensure scaled inputs improve gradient-based models like XGBoost.
